Query: Copy files from one directory into an existing directory

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Recursively copy a directory's contents to another location (if the destination exists, the directory is copied inside it)
Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Recursively copy all files and folders in the current directory excluding "exclude_pattern" to "/to/where/"

rsync.mpsum: a fast, versatile, remote (and local) file-copying tool
rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

Top-3 Scripts:
so_30382268: for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN.`echo $d | sed 's/[\.\/]//g;s/Event_//:'`.BHZ"
fi
done

i=0;
for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN-$((++i)).BHZ"
fi
done

for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN.`echo $d | sed 's/[\.\/]//g;s/Event_//:'`_`date '+%Y-%m-%d'`.BHZ"
fi
done

su_1022048: today=`date +%Y-%m-%d`
ls -A src/ | while f=`line`; do if [ ! -f "dst/*/$f" ]; \
                 then mkdir -p "dst/$today"; cp "src/$f" "dst/$today/$f"; fi; done

su_1022048: today=`date +%Y-%m-%d`

                 then mkdir -p "dst/$today"; cp "src/$f" "dst/$today/$f"; fi; done

so_36142838: mkdir -p

while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

rsync.mpsum: a fast, versatile, remote (and local) file-copying tool
rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

ul_41770: How can I copy a file and create the target directories at the same time?

so_36142838: while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

Top-3 Scripts:
so_42827465: #!/bin/bash

dateToday="$(date +%d%m%Y)"

while IFS= read -r file; do
    [ -f "$file" ] && printf "%s\n"  "$file$dateToday" >> files.OK || printf "%s\n"  "$file" >> files.NOK
done < files.txt

This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging

rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

Explanations about Options.-z:
With this option, rsync compresses the file data as it is sent to the destination
 machine, which reduces the amount of data being transmitted - something that is
 useful over a slow connection.
Explanations about Options.-a:
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.
Explanations about Options.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
Explanations about Options.-v:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
Explanations about Options.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.
Explanations about Options.--include:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an include
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.
Explanations about Options.--prune-empty-dirs:
This option tells the receiving rsync to get rid of empty directories from the
 file-list, including nested directories that have no non-directory children. This
 is useful for avoiding the creation of a bunch of useless directories when the
 sending rsync is recursively scanning a hierarchy of files using
 include/exclude/filter rules.

Top-3 Similar Questions: su_1022048: Copy files that don't exist in higher directory
so_42827465: Comparing the file's existence from a file and in current directory using shell script
so_36142838: Copy files from list while keeping subdirectory structure
Top-3 Scripts: su_1022048: while read f; ...

so_42827465: #!/bin/bash

dateToday="$(date +%d%m%Y)"

while IFS= read -r file; do
    [ -f "$file" ] && printf "%s\n"  "$file$dateToday" >> files.OK || printf "%s\n"  "$file" >> files.NOK
done < files.txt

so_36142838: while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

Top-3 Scripts:
so_67038100: find foo -type d -exec bash -c "d=\"{}\"; dnew=\$(echo \$d | sed 's/^foo/tmp/') ; mkdir -p \$dnew ; chmod --reference=\$d \$dnew ; chown --reference=\$d \$dnew ; touch --reference=\$d \$dnew " \;

> chmod --reference=olddir newdir # we copy modes rwx,
> chown --reference=olddir newdir # we copy owner,
> touch --reference=olddir newdir # we copy dates.

Explanations about Options.--reference: use RFILE's owner and group rather than specifying OWNER:GROUP values

Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_42827465: Comparing the file's existence from a file and in current directory using shell script
ul_381373: search for directories containing one file and missing another
Top-3 Scripts:
so_42827465: #!/bin/bash

dateToday="$(date +%d%m%Y)"

while IFS= read -r file; do
    [ -f "$file" ] && printf "%s\n"  "$file$dateToday" >> files.OK || printf "%s\n"  "$file" >> files.NOK
done < files.txt

ul_381373: for dir in */; do [ ! -e "$dir"/"$filename" ] || printf '%s\n' "$dir"; done

for dir in */; do 
    [ ! -e "$dir"/"$filename1" ] && 
    [ -e "$dir"/"$filename2" ] && 
    printf '%s\n' "$dir"; 
done

for dir in */; do 
    if [ ! -e "$dir"/"$filename1" ]; then 
        if [ -e "$dir"/"$filename2" ]; then 
            printf '%s\n' "$dir"; 
        fi 
    fi
 done

Top-3 Scripts:

while read -r file; do
    new_dir="new_directory/$(dirname "$file")"
    #        ^ this is the new directory root
    mkdir -p "$new_dir"
    cp "$file" "$new_dir/$file"
done < <(cat /path/to/files.txt)

Explanations about Options.-c:
Create a new archive. Arguments supply the names of the files to be archived.
 Directories are archived recursively, unless the --no-recursion option is given.
Explanations about Options.-T: Get names to extract or create from FILE.
Explanations about Options.-C:
Change to DIR before performing any operations. This option is order-sensitive,
 i.e. it affects all options that follow.

Explanations about Options.-t:
The argument following the -t is used to indicate the filesystem type. The
 filesystem types which are currently supported depend on the running kernel. See
 /proc/filesystems and /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/kernel/fs for a complete list of the
 filesystems. The most common are ext2, ext3, ext4, xfs, btrfs, vfat, sysfs, proc,
 nfs and cifs.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Use the specified mount options. The opts argument is a comma-separated list. For
 example:

Explanations about Options.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.
Explanations about Options.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_30382268: If a file exists, copy another file, but don't overwrite
Top-3 Scripts:
so_30382268: for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN.`echo $d | sed 's/[\.\/]//g;s/Event_//:'`.BHZ"
fi
done

i=0;
for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN-$((++i)).BHZ"
fi
done

for d in ./Event_*/; do
set -- "$d/"*.mcp
if [ -e "$1" ]; then
    cp -rp -v -- "$d/KNYN.BHZ" "./newdir/KNYN.`echo $d | sed 's/[\.\/]//g;s/Event_//:'`_`date '+%Y-%m-%d'`.BHZ"
fi
done

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_42827465: Comparing the file's existence from a file and in current directory using shell script
Top-3 Scripts:
so_42827465: #!/bin/bash

dateToday="$(date +%d%m%Y)"

while IFS= read -r file; do
    [ -f "$file" ] && printf "%s\n"  "$file$dateToday" >> files.OK || printf "%s\n"  "$file" >> files.NOK
done < files.txt

rsync.mpsum: a fast, versatile, remote (and local) file-copying tool
rsync.--verbose:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
rsync.-r: This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
rsync.--exclude:
This option is a simplified form of the --filter option that defaults to an exclude
 rule and does not allow the full rule-parsing syntax of normal filter rules.

to.mpsum: as the filename. --logdir <name> Writes each synchronization log output in a new file in the specified directory. --logexpire <hours> Removes logs older than the value specified (in hours). This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory. The ownCloud Client reads a configuration file.  You can locate this configuration file as follows: On Linux distributions: $HOME/.config/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg On Microsoft Windows systems: %APPDATA%\ownCloud\owncloud.cfg On MAC OS X systems: $HOME/Library/Preferences/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg The configuration file contains settings using the Microsoft Windows .ini file format. You can overwrite changes using the ownCloud configuration dialog. NOTE: Use caution when making changes to the ownCloud Client configuration  file.   Incorrect settings can produce unintended results. remote │ │                            │         │ repository            in │ │                            │         │ milliseconds.            │ a │ │                            │         │ synchronization      run │ │                            │         │ shall    be    triggered │ │                            │         │ automatically. synchronization │ │                            │         │ will   perform   a  full │ │                            │         │ local discovery.         │ of one or more patterns separated by either | or &. ... The following list
describes valid sub-patterns.

...
